captions.text:
There’s a whole lore about dreaming. In
fact, Sigmund Freud wrote a book called The

Interpretation of Dreams which many people
think is the foundation of psychoanalysis.

Well scientists now have looked at Freudian
psychology and the brain using all these modern

techniques. And first of all we realize that
perhaps Sigmund Freud wasn’t totally wrong.

There are many textbooks which simply dismiss
Freudian psychology calling it nuts. That

is nothing but the sexual fantasies of a repressed
Venetian scientist of the last century. But

now we realize there’s more to it. First
of all the unconscious mind. We can actually

see the brain in motion and we realize that
much of the activity is totally unconscious.
Just like what Freud predicted.

And Freud also said there is the ego, the
id and the superego, that we are in a constant

battle with our desires and our conscious.
And we see that now with brain scans. The

ego is basically your prefrontal cortex. That
is who you are. When you wonder where am I

anyway. Well, you’re right there. You are
sitting right behind your forehead. And then

your desires. We see the pleasure center right
there at the center of the brain. That is

the libido. We see where the pleasure center
is located. And then your conscience is right

behind your eyes. The orbital frontal cortex
right behind your eyes is where your conscience
is. And so we actually see that in motion.

If you were to see a chocolate cake you would
see these three parts of the brain going zippity

back and forth like a ping pong ball because
you’re constantly debating the pleasure

of eating a chocolate cake versus how fat
you’re gonna become and all the sugar and

the calories that you don’t really need.
So we see the beginnings of Freudian psychology

coming out of brain scans. And now dreams.
Freud had a whole collection of interpretation

of dreams. Scientists have looked at and said,
“Nonsense.” Now we understand the physiology

of the dreaming process. And we realize that
it comes at the back of the brain, the very

primitive part of the brain and that certain
parts of the brain are shut off when you dream.

First of all your prefrontal cortex is basically
shut off, it’s quiet. Your orbital frontal

cortex that is your conscience is also shut
off. But that part of the brain is your fact

checker. The part of the brain that said,
“Hmmm, that’s not right. Something’s

wrong” is right behind your eyes. That’s
shut off.

What is active when you dream is your amygdala.
Now what does your amygdala govern? Fear and

emotions. And so right then you know that
when you dream the active part of the brain

is not the fact checker, not the rational
brain – it’s the emotional brain, the

fearful brain that is active when you dream.
And then there’s some superstition called

lucid dreaming where you can actually control
the direction of the dream. Well that superstition

last year became science fact. At the Max
Planck Institute in Germany they were able

to show once and for all that lucid dreaming
is testable, reproducible – it is real.

And here’s how they did it. They took a
person who was about to go to sleep and told

them that when you dream clench your right
fist and then clench your left fist. Now when

you dream you are paralyzed. You cannot move
when you dream.

Otherwise we’d be able to carry out all
sorts of horrible things and destroy ourselves.

So we are paralyzed when we dream. But when
this person went into a dream state you can

clearly see that the brain initiated orders
to clench your right fist and your left fist.

In other words, he was conscious while he
was dreaming. There are many Buddhist texts,

many texts hundreds of years old that give
you the outlines of how to control dreams.

Lucid dreaming. We now know that it’s not
hogwash that you can actually do this. You

can actually direct the course of your dream.
And then one day we may be able to brain scan

the brain as you dream and put it on a screen.
In which case somebody will be able to see

you dream and know the direction of the dream
and you are conscious of the process. In other

words, the movie Inception is not totally
hogwash.

comments.text:
Scientists suggest that most of the time, our behaviors and decisions that 
we make in everyday life are related to our *unconscious mind*. Most people 
probably would be surprised by this statement.
Dr. Michio Kaku in the video of *"the Science of Dreams"* provides 
scientific facts about how our brain work when we are awake and while we 
are in sleep. He also discusses if *lucid dreaming* is possible or not in 
this video.
#brain #neuroscience #dream #luciddreaming #michiokaku  ﻿

comments.author: ChangeTip

comments.text:
+Big Think I have an interesting story to share with you about my lucid 
dreaming (small wall of text below)...

Around the time I was 20 years old (about 4.5 years ago), I conducted an 
experiment to see if I could use my lucid dreaming to view into my past 
memories and possibly re-live them instead of just having a dream, then 
controlling it halfway in. Most of my normal dreams seemed to be centered 
around my emotions and how I truly felt about things going on in my current 
life, so I had a good feeling my memories were connected to strong 
emotions. Anyway, it took about 3 nights to pull off, but I did it. 
However, there was a catch...

In the dream, I put myself in a long, white hallway with a door at the end, 
much like the 2nd Matrix movie in the Keymaker scene, but I understood 
there were memories behind this door. So I walked to the door, grabbed the 
doorknob, and only cracked the door open wide enough to peak in...and...I 
relived EVERY single thing I've ever regretted since I was 3 years 
old...even the smallest things like forgetting to vacuum the living room 
before my parents got home or something. I can't exactly recall the 
memories I saw anymore. I assume it's stored away in my subconscious mind. 
But the memories went backwards in time in chronological order and they 
stopped when I was 3 years old, and then repeated. You can only imagine 
just how much I witnessed if a 3 year old had something to regret lol.

The memories were so intense that it woke me up from my sleep, and I could 
still see these memories flashing before my eyes one after another in the 
darkness of my room for about 10-15 seconds, as they slowly faded away. The 
whole ordeal seemed to only last 20 seconds including when I woke up from 
the dream. That means I was seeing multiple memories every second, but I 
could see them all as clear as a night sky in Texas.

So, I haven't tried to do it again since then. Not only did I have a 
"laundry list" of factors I had to overcome the first time but if I can't 
control which "door" I'm going to be peaking into next time, then I'm 
afraid to even try it again. 

And I can't stress enough how intense this dream was though. I wish I 
possessed the proper literary skills to describe just how intense it was 
but I'll try to sum it up: It's similar to how I feel on roller coasters 
and I'm afraid of heights. That dream really messed up my mood for a full 
24 hours and it left me with a pretty good headache....and I only opened my 
"door of regrets". Just imagine if it were my "door of sorrows".﻿
comments.author: WuKingdom1

comments.text:
In my situation, I did.  But also heard from other persons with 
experience.  What I am trying to say is, if you do go to see a 
psychologist, which may be necessary or not, it should be one who also 
knows about regressions and perhaps who is also a psychic, for lack of a 
better word for those manifestations of the mind which are not totally 
discovered or accepted by science.  What I am trying to say is, and I am 
sorry to say it, not all psychologist are able to help in some matters and 
if we are not careful choosing one, they can even mix up the situation or 
even the mind.  On the other side, experiences like the one you had are 
not totally uncommon and they may happen once in life and that's all.  If 
you feel you have a need to go more deeply into these kind of experiences, 
with help, I wish you could find a very good person who could help you 
successfully, otherwise better to wait till the appropriate time comes to 
do it.

comments.text:
I am sure Kaku has explained or will explain more about dreams.  There is 
much more to it.  He did mention Budhism, because of the way they 
meditate.  What you did, for what I understand, was a regression, something 
to be done under experienced professionals. 
I did have once a similar dream, in one sense.  I went to a hospital 
looking for my record, but the record keeper was away.  I insisted to see 
him and they told me he was inside a column next to where I was standing, 
outside from the record archives.  I went straight to the column and opened 
a small door.  He was a bat, hanging next to the small door.  When he saw 
the light he sent me a striking look, he was so angry and disturbed!
I asked a few persons and a psicologist and the answer was that I was not 
ready yet to know what was written in my record, meaning I was not ready 
yet to know all about certain aspects of my life.  When the moment comes, 
then we should do it through meditation guided by an expert.  This is what 
I learned.  I hope it is useful.

comments.text:
#Poetry....  By +Michael Montoya 

Your Soul Mate...

Together...  forever
what once was.. will be again..
the sands of time flow eternal..
 View the stars.. they were once ours
 as we stared ...holding each other
knowing we were immortal.. in our love
 and yet we would pass
 into stardust once again...
 For time escapes none.. but Love..
knows no boundaries of time and distance...
 I have carried your heart...
 across the many spheres of  Loves ethereal legends..
 Zeus and Ganymede.. Apollo and Hyacinthus...
 Romeo and Juliet...
Yes... all  are still  waiting for their own time
 to once again be together..  Now
 We.. will be one star in the sky ..
looked upon as Lovers...across the Universe
  keep hope in their hearts..
that they will soon be
One Again... My Love..
My Soul Mate..

Written by Michael Montoya.. 11/9/2014 at11:50 AM.﻿

comments.author: hehe13

comments.text:
KooKoo Kaku never misses a chance to prove he's a world class buffoon that 
constantly gets things wrong.

Here he babbled your muscles are paralyzed when you dream. BULLSHIT! You 
heart is a muscle. It doesn't stop beating when you dream or you would be 
dead. Your diaphragm, a dome shaped sheet of muscles contracts in 
conjunction with the intercostal muscles, which lowers the pressure in the 
thoracic cavity enabling air to enter the lungs. Stop breathing, again 
you're dead.

Anyone that has a dog probably has seen it dreaming, confirmed by the (REM) 
rapid eye movement, again which while small still one of the more powerful 
muscles in your body. 

Now if he would have said your voluntary muscles are paralyzed, he'd almost 
be right (eye muscles are voluntary in how they move up/down, left/right as 
seen in REM sleep, movement under eyelids)

My main complaint about Kuku for the scientist he pretends to be he's often 
grossly sloppy in his facts and constantly pretends to be expert on 
everything. Which clearly he is not. Therefore he is a lousy spokesperson 
for science. 

If you want to voodoo science, fake science, mistake riddled science or bad 
science ficton, Kaku is your man. Otherwise he's a laughingstock.﻿
comments.author: willieofroanoke

comments.author: WAKE UPpeople

comments.text:
Dreams are a big mystery, but the moment of waking up is a mind-blower.  I 
once had a nightmare that I was standing in a field, and I turned around to 
see a large male African lion staring at me a few meters away.  It 
frightened me so much that I just stood there paralyzed as the lion lunged 
toward me, scaring me awake in a cold sweat.  After several seconds, I 
realized I was awake and still paralyzed!  Maybe awakening is a more 
gradual process than it seems afterward.  Sir Arthur Eddington once said 
"Not only is the universe stranger than we imagine, it is stranger than we 
*can* imagine."...  the same could be argued for that 'inner space' between 
our ears!﻿

comments.author: sd86it

comments.text: Carl G. Jung, had a very good understanding of dreams.﻿
comments.author: Laberinto Azul

comments.text:
I love how people still blindly assume that unless you have a piece of 
paper that "signifies" your knowledge of a subject: you cannot possibly 
know or understand anything about that subject. We all know that piece of 
paper represents the extent to which a person has gone to acquire knowledge 
in a certain area, but that in no way discredits or invalidates the words 
and ideas of people whom have acquired knowledge through other means.

In fact, in certain cases there are intelligent people whom do not have the 
proper documentation to back up their intelligence but nonetheless know 
more about a subject then some people who merely memorized the work of 
others. Initiative is so incredibly important especially when it comes to 
acquiring knowledge: we must be able to *understand* and not just be able 
to *know* why others have made certain conclusions.

Even with little knowledge of the subject area we can fact-check and 
understand that Kaku also understands what he is talking about. Lastly, I 
talk about things related to the individual's experience of the human 
condition and the perceptions and problems that emanate from it. Give me a 
shot if you're interested as I am always learning:) Good day to everyone﻿
comments.author: SpiritofSix

comments.text:
i think lucid dreaming exist but not in the same way Michio explained, our 
consciousness does go away, what we were thinking of doing as an order 
remain and our subconscious mind just execute them accordingly.....the 
unconscious mind knows the consciousness mind more than anything, and so it 
will perform the same decision as a consciousness mind would, that is why 
when people wake up and remember the dream they realize the decisions made 
in the dream is exactly as what they would have decided to do, and thus 
thinking they were controlling it...dreams to me is more like a simulation 
that take what we afraid most and play them for us to prepare us for real 
life in case we did face our fears.﻿
comments.author: se7en the great

comments.text: love michio kaku's creative thinking﻿

comments.text: science is finally catching up with religion :)﻿
comments.author: razor blade

comments.text:
Now that was one of the more truly fun videos I have watched. I would like 
to see Michio take deeper steps in this realm and discuss the primary 
driver of the dream state, the release of DMT during this process.

There are also chemical states which enhance dreaming and ones which 
suppress dreaming. I think science is at the very early stages of 
understanding much of what goes on. I hope they continue their work.﻿
comments.author: Steve Kusaba

comments.text:
Dr Michio Kaku is a great scientist but I don't understand why they ask him 
questions that is not in his filed of expertise? 
I prefer to see Dr Michio Kaku talks about Physics rather than dream, 
evolution, how brain works or biology.   ﻿
comments.author: Aryan Zagros

comments.text:
+Vrig I totally agree.  "things" are connected, therefore also knowledge.  
To explain an understanding of all at the same time is not possible, 
therefore explain one thing a little and  in the meantime give hints of 
other connected areas is much better, and those who have already some 
understanding of those connections understand what he is talking about, or 
feel prompted to inquire more about the hint. This is how I see it.
comments.author: maga lee

comments.text:
This is because he is largely a science popularizer, just like Neil 
DeGrasse Tyson, and Bill Nye. He probably would not do a lecture to other 
top scientists in this field, but explaining a simplified version of the 
ideas to the general public is not a problem at all.
comments.author: Nathan Kirse

comments.text:
Seeing as how his point was that scans (nuclear magnetic resonance imaging) 
have revealed that psychology-babel isn't "hogwash", as he put it, it does 
revolve around physics. Electromagnetic waves to detect neural signals and 
paths and map out the brain activity with psychological boundary 
conditions. Sounds like physics to me.

Sounds like you have no idea of how the scientific field evolves.. maybe 
you should read up on it? You know that if you become a chemist, you also 
learn about physics and biology? And the fields in which these chemists 
work can be anything from food processing to materials to medicin, etc etc. 
Thus a chemist may know a thing or two about things other than chemistry. 
As goes for physicists..
comments.author: Vrig

comments.text:
I never knew the concept of lucid dreaming was even under dispute.  It 
doesn't happen often but there have been times where I become aware that I 
am dream and then take control of the dream.  I thought this was something 
most people experience.﻿
comments.author: CampingforCool41

comments.text:
+Vrig
Ah.  I thought they had meant that the experience of lucid dream was under 
dispute, which would be ludicrous.  That makes more sense.
comments.author: CampingforCool41

comments.text:
It is. But the "human experience" isn't proof of anything. Now they have 
proof to back up the claims. One could for instance assume that your 
"choices" are actually fabricated without you, you only experience them as 
choices and thus believe them to be just that. Now they have shown that it 
is, infact, the conciousness which dictates the terms of the dream.
